choices.text: It is part of the ethmoid bone and lies within the middle meatus
Its mucosa contains vascular channels running anterior to posterior
It attaches anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone
It plays no role in humidifying inspired air

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the inferior turbinate is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It attaches anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone

 

The inferior turbinate is a separate bone that is attached anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone. It also connects to the lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is part of the ethmoid bone and lies within the middle meatus: Incorrect. The inferior turbinate is a separate bone, unlike the superior and middle turbinates, which are part of the ethmoid bone. Also, it lies in the inferior meatus, not middle.

 

Option B. Its mucosa contains vascular channels running anterior to posterior: Incorrect. The vascular channels in the mucosa run from posterior to anterior, not anterior to posterior. This orientation helps maintain long contact with inspired air for effective humidification.

 

Option D. It plays no role in humidifying inspired air: Incorrect. The inferior turbinate plays a significant role in humidifying inspired air due to its vascular mucosa, which helps condition the air before it reaches the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:


The inferior turbinate is a separate bone attached to the maxilla and palatine bone, with posterior-to-anterior vascular channels in its mucosa aiding in humidification of inspired air.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 135

choices.text: The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that may lie close to the optic nerve
Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess
The superior turbinate is a separate bone that marks the opening of the frontal sinus
The sphenoid sinus opens into the superior meatus, lateral to the middle turbinate

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy around the superior turbinate is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that may lie close to the optic nerve

 

The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that may pneumatize near or even over the optic nerve, making it clinically significant during sinus surgery. Mnemonic: OO = Onodi–Optic.

 

 

Arrow marked structures are onodi cells and star shaped structures are sphenoid sinuses

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess: Incorrect. Posterior ethmoidal air cells open into the superior meatus, not the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

 

Option C. The superior turbinate is a separate bone that marks the opening of the frontal sinus: Incorrect. The superior turbinate is part of the ethmoid bone, not a separate bone, and it marks the sphenoid ostium, not the frontal sinus opening.

 

 

Option D. The sphenoid sinus opens into the superior meatus, lateral to the middle turbinate: Incorrect. The sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is above and medial to the superior turbinate, not into the superior meatus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that lies close to the optic nerve and is important to identify during endoscopic sinus surgery.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 137

choices.text: The superior turbinate is part of the maxillary bone and is located anterior to the middle turbinate
The superior turbinate lies lateral to the sphenoid sinus ostium and is derived from the frontal bone
The superior turbinate is the main drainage site for the anterior ethmoid and maxillary sinuses
The superior turbinate is an ethmoturbinal, located posterior and superior to the middle turbinate, and serves as a key landmark for identifying the sphenoid sinus ostium

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the superior turbinate is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The superior turbinate is an ethmoturbinal, located posterior and superior to the middle turbinate, and serves as a key landmark for identifying the sphenoid sinus ostium

 

The superior turbinate is an ethmoturbinal, located posterior and superior to the middle turbinate, and is a reliable endoscopic landmark to locate the sphenoid sinus ostium, which lies medial to it.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The superior turbinate is part of the maxillary bone and is located anterior to the middle turbinate: Incorrect. The superior turbinate is not derived from the maxillary bone and is not located anterior to the middle turbinate. It is part of the ethmoid bone and lies posterior and superior.

 

Option B. The superior turbinate lies lateral to the sphenoid sinus ostium and is derived from the frontal bone: Incorrect. The sphenoid ostium lies medial, not lateral, to the superior turbinate. The turbinate itself is not derived from the frontal bone.

 

Option C. The superior turbinate is the main drainage site for the anterior ethmoid and maxillary sinuses: Incorrect. The superior turbinate is not involved in drainage of anterior ethmoid or maxillary sinuses. These drain into the middle meatus, not near the superior turbinate.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The superior turbinate is an ethmoturbinal that lies posterior and superior to the middle turbinate and helps identify the sphenoid sinus ostium located medial to it.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: Surgical section of the vidian nerve via the pterygopalatine fossa
Application of anesthetic to the anterior ethmoidal nerve at the cribriform plate
Resection of infraorbital nerve branches at the nasal vestibule
Local anesthetic pledget placement near the middle turbinate to block sphenopalatine ganglion

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent watery nasal discharge that worsens with temperature changes and exposure to strong smells. He is diagnosed with vasomotor rhinitis that has not responded to antihistamines or intranasal steroids. The ENT surgeon plans a procedure to reduce parasympathetic innervation to the nasal mucosa and control his rhinorrhoea. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical section of the vidian nerve via the pterygopalatine fossa

 

The vidian nerve (nerve of the pterygoid canal) carries parasympathetic fibers (from greater superficial petrosal nerve) and sympathetic fibers (from deep petrosal nerve). Parasympathetic fibers synapse in the sphenopalatine ganglion and supply nasal glands, promoting secretion. Sectioning the vidian nerve surgically reduces nasal secretion, making it a treatment for refractory vasomotor or allergic rhinitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Application of anesthetic to the anterior ethmoidal nerve at the cribriform plate: Incorrect. The anterior ethmoidal nerve is a branch of the nasociliary nerve (V1) and carries general sensory innervation to the anterior-superior nasal cavity. It has no effect on autonomic control of nasal glands.

 

Option C. Resection of infraorbital nerve branches at the nasal vestibule: Incorrect. The infraorbital nerve is a branch of V2 that supplies the vestibule of the nose. It provides somatic sensation, not autonomic control, and resection would not reduce rhinorrhoea.

 

 

Option D. Local anesthetic pledget placement near the middle turbinate to block sphenopalatine ganglion: Incorrect. A pledget near the sphenopalatine foramen can temporarily block sensory and autonomic fibers for procedures or diagnostic blocks but is not a definitive treatment for chronic rhinitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Surgical section of the vidian nerve reduces parasympathetic stimulation to nasal glands and is used to treat refractory vasomotor rhinitis with excessive rhinorrhoea.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: The membranous septum lies posterior to the perpendicular plate of ethmoid
The columellar septum is made up of septal cartilage and covered by nasal mucosa
The perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to the bony part of the septum proper
The membranous septum is supported by the vomer and palatine crest

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes a component of the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to the bony part of the septum proper

 

  • It forms the superior portion of the osteocartilaginous septum proper.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The membranous septum lies posterior to the perpendicular plate of ethmoid: Incorrect. The membranous septum lies anterior to the septal cartilage, not posterior to the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid.

 

Option B. The columellar septum is made up of septal cartilage and covered by nasal mucosa: Incorrect. The columellar septum consists of the medial crura of the alar cartilages, united by fibrous tissue and covered by skin, not mucosa.

 

Option D. The membranous septum is supported by the vomer and palatine crest: Incorrect. The membranous septum has no bony or cartilaginous support, consisting only of skin layers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The perpendicular plate of ethmoid is a major bony component of the septum proper, forming the superior part of the nasal septum.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 147

choices.text: Prescribe oral decongestants and monitor
Incision and drainage with bilateral nasal packing
Immediate septoplasty
Reassure and follow-up after a week

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and headache after a fall during a football match. On anterior rhinoscopy, a smooth, soft, fluctuant swelling is seen on both sides of the septum. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage with bilateral nasal packing

 

This is the treatment of choice for large septal haematomas. Drainage prevents complications like septal abscess, cartilage necrosis, and saddle nose deformity. Packing prevents reaccumulation of blood, and antibiotics are given to prevent infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe oral decongestants and monitor: Incorrect. This approach delays definitive treatment. Septal haematomas can lead to cartilage necrosis and deformity if not drained promptly.

 

Option C. Immediate septoplasty: Incorrect. Septoplasty is indicated for deviated nasal septum, not for haematoma. Surgical drainage is sufficient unless structural deformity develops later.

 

Option D. Reassure and follow-up after a week: Incorrect. Delay in treatment may lead to secondary infection and irreversible cartilage damage. Timely intervention is critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septal haematoma must be promptly incised and drained with nasal packing to prevent complications like septal abscess and saddle nose deformity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 149

choices.text: Nasopalatine Nerve
Anterior Ethmoidal Nerve
Both A & B
Vidian Nerve Block

questions.text: Which of the following Nerve/Nerves should be blocked in a patient who was to undergo Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy (DNE):
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Option C: Anesthetizing both the nasopalatine and anterior ethmoidal nerves could potentially provide comprehensive anesthesia to the nasal septum and the anterior nasal cavity, which may be beneficial during a DNE.

 

 

Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy (DNE) is a procedure used to visualize the interior of the nasal passages and the openings into the paranasal sinuses. To perform a DNE with minimal discomfort, local anesthesia is often applied to the nasal mucosa. The choice of nerve to anesthetize will depend on the areas that need to be anesthetized.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nasopalatine Nerve supplies the septal mucosa of the anterior part of the hard palate and the adjacent nasal septum. While local anesthetic may be applied to the area supplied by this nerve, it's not typically the primary focus for a DNE.

 

Option B. Anterior Ethmoidal Nerve provides sensation to the anterior part of the nasal cavity. Anesthetizing this nerve can help reduce discomfort during DNE, particularly when inspecting the anterior and superior parts of the nasal cavity.

 

Option D. Vidian Nerve Block is not directly involved in sensation to the nasal cavity. It carries parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland and the mucous glands of the nasal cavity and palate. Blocking the vidian nerve is not a procedure associated with DNE.

 

The most suitable nerve block for a patient undergoing DNE would typically involve the anterior ethmoidal nerve because it innervates the region that is most relevant to the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient undergoing diagnostic nasal endoscopy, blocking the nasopalatine nerve (Option A) and anterior ethmoidal nerve (Option B) is most appropriate to provide local anesthesia to the areas that will be inspected during the procedure. Knowledge of nasal anatomy and innervation is essential for medical students and residents who perform or assist with such procedures.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, Pg 180

choices.text: Asch Forceps
Walsham Forceps
Alligator Forceps
Tilley Forceps

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with recurrent epistaxis. Upon examination, the ENT specialist decides to perform nasal packing. Which of the following instruments would be most appropriate for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tilley forceps

 

Option D. The correct answer is D. Tilley forceps, with their long reach and angled tips, are ideal for nasal packing in epistaxis. They allow for precise placement and control of the packing material within the nasal cavity.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Asch forceps are specifically designed for the management of nasal fractures and for manipulating the septum. They are not typically used for nasal packing in epistaxis management.

 

 

Option B. Walsham forceps are used in nasal procedures, primarily for straightening the nasal septum. However, they are not the ideal choice for nasal packing in the case of epistaxis.

 

 

Option C. Alligator forceps, with their long, slender design and small, serrated jaws, are used for foreign body removal and precise manipulations in the nasal cavity. They are not typically used for nasal packing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of epistaxis, Tilley forceps are the most suitable instrument for nasal packing, due to their design which facilitates precise control and placement of packing materials within the nasal cavity. Understanding the specific utility of various ENT instruments, like Asch and Walsham forceps, is crucial for medical residents, particularly in the field of otolaryngology.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, Pg 176-180

choices.text: Immediate Surgical Open Reduction and Fixation
Closed Reduction of the Nasal Bone Fracture within 3-6 hours
Administration of Antibiotics and Delayed Closed Reduction in 5-7 days
No intervention, as Nasal Bone Fractures often Heal Without Treatment

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining a nasal injury during a basketball game. Examination reveals a deviated nasal septum and a displaced nasal bone fracture. The patient is stable and shows no signs of septal hematoma or other complications. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administration of Antibiotics and Delayed Closed Reduction in 5-7 days

 

Option C: The correct answer is C. Closed reduction of a nasal bone fracture is usually performed within 5-7 days after the injury. This allows time for initial swelling to subside, which makes the procedure easier and more effective. Antibiotics are given to prevent infection, especially if there's a risk of a septal hematoma. Asch and Walsham forceps are used for this. Asch forceps is used for septal reduction and Walsham forceps is used for nasal bone reduction.


 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immediate surgical open reduction and fixation: This approach is generally reserved for complex nasal fractures, especially those involving other facial structures or when closed reduction is unsuccessful. It is not the first-line treatment for an isolated nasal bone fracture.

 

Option B. Closed reduction of the nasal bone fracture within 3-6 hours: Closed reduction is typically not performed immediately due to the development of swelling. Immediate reduction is also challenging due to the acute pain and bleeding.

 

Option D. No intervention, as nasal bone fractures often heal without treatment: While some minor nasal fractures can heal without intervention, a displaced fracture, especially with a deviated septum, typically requires reduction to prevent long-term cosmetic and functional issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a displaced nasal bone fracture with a deviated septum, the appropriate management is the administration of antibiotics and closed reduction performed 5-7 days after the injury. This timeline allows for the reduction of initial swelling and provides a more favorable outcome.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, Pg 176-180

choices.text: Oral Antibiotics and Outpatient Follow-Ip
Immediate Incision and Drainage in the Emergency Department
Nasal Decongestants and Analgesics
Observation and Cold Compresses

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with Nasal Trauma sustained during a Soccer Game. On examination, he has a Tender Fluctuant Swelling of the Nasal Septum. There is no evidence of nasal bone fracture or other facial injuries. The most likely diagnosis is a Septal Hematoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate Incision and Drainage in the Emergency Department 

 

Option B.

 

The correct answer is B. A septal hematoma should be drained as soon as possible to prevent complications like cartilage necrosis and septal perforation. This is usually done through a small incision under local anesthesia in the emergency department.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While antibiotics are important to prevent infection, they are not sufficient as the sole treatment for a septal hematoma. A septal hematoma requires active intervention to prevent complications.

 

Option C. Nasal decongestants and analgesics may provide symptomatic relief for nasal congestion and pain but do not address the underlying issue of a septal hematoma.

 

Option D. While cold compresses can help reduce swelling, observation alone is not an appropriate management strategy for a septal hematoma due to the risk of complications.

 

Septal hematoma –

 

Collection of blood between cartilage and it’s perichondrium.

 

 

 

Causes – trauma, surgery, bleeding disorders.

 

Clinical features – Bilateral obstruction, frontal headache, sense of pressure over nasal bridge.

 

Examination – smooth rounded swelling of septum in both cavities.

 

On palpation → soft & fluctuant.

 

Treatment – Incision & drainage immediately, then packing + antibiotics.

 

Complications –

 

(1) Fibrous Change → permanently thickened septum.

(2) Secondary Infection → abscess with cartilage necrosis → Dorsum Depressed (Saddling).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a septal hematoma involves immediate incision and drainage in the emergency department to prevent complications like cartilage necrosis and septal perforation. This knowledge is essential for medical residents, particularly in emergency medicine and otolaryngology, for the effective management of nasal trauma-related complications.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, Pg 176-180

choices.text: Nasal obstruction reduces filtration of large particles, leading to direct alveolar damage.
Impaired nasal humidification decreases ciliary function, affecting mucociliary clearance and gas exchange.
Loss of nasal vibrissae function causes excessive warming of inspired air, resulting in hyperthermia.
Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids constrict excessively, reducing oxygen absorption in the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic nasal obstruction complains of frequent episodes of dry cough and worsened breathing at night. Pulmonary function tests show mild hypoxemia and elevated arterial pCO₂. Which of the following best explains how nasal obstruction can contribute to these respiratory abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired nasal humidification decreases ciliary function, affecting mucociliary clearance and gas exchange.

 

The nasal mucosa humidifies inspired air to maintain relative humidity around 75% or more. Dry air due to nasal obstruction reduces humidification, leading to impaired ciliary function (which stops within 8–10 minutes at 50% humidity). This impairs mucociliary clearance, predisposing to respiratory infections and reduces effective gas exchange in the lungs, leading to hypoxemia and elevated pCO₂.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal obstruction reduces filtration of large particles, leading to direct alveolar damage: Incorrect. While the nose filters larger particles using vibrissae and mucus, direct alveolar damage from reduced filtration is less common; smaller particles <0.5 μm bypass the nose normally.

 

Option C. Loss of nasal vibrissae function causes excessive warming of inspired air, resulting in hyperthermia: Incorrect. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids act as a “radiator” warming or cooling inspired air to body temperature, but loss of vibrissae does not cause excessive warming or hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids constrict excessively, reducing oxygen absorption in the nasal cavity: Incorrect. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids regulate blood flow to control temperature, but oxygen absorption does not occur in the nasal cavity; oxygen exchange happens in the lungs.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Nasal vibrissae filter large particles (>3 μm), while mucus traps finer particles (0.5–3 μm).
  • Inspired air temperature is rapidly adjusted from cold or hot ambient temperature to near 37°C within one-fourth second.
  • Approximately 1000 mL of water evaporates daily from nasal mucosa, crucial for humidification and ciliary function.
  • Nasal obstruction can impair lung function, causing apneic spells and altered blood gases during sleep.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal obstruction impairs humidification of inspired air, leading to decreased ciliary function and compromised gas exchange, resulting in hypoxemia and elevated pCO₂.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 140

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis; start intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines.
Viral rhinitis; prescribe bed rest and symptomatic treatment.
Irritative rhinitis; remove offending agent and provide supportive care.
Bacterial rhinitis; start systemic antibiotics immediately.

questions.text: A 30-year-old factory worker presents with sudden onset sneezing, nasal congestion, and watery nasal discharge immediately after exposure to strong ammonia fumes at work. Symptoms improve after leaving the exposure but recur intermittently. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irritative rhinitis; remove offending agent and provide supportive care.

 

Irritative rhinitis is caused by exposure to irritant gases (ammonia, formalin, acid fumes), dust, smoke, or trauma to nasal mucosa. It causes an immediate catarrhal reaction with sneezing, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion. Removal of the offending agent is the primary management. Symptoms usually resolve quickly unless mucosal damage or secondary infection occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis; start intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction and usually has a history of allergen exposure and chronic symptoms rather than immediate reaction to irritant gases.

 

Option B. Viral rhinitis; prescribe bed rest and symptomatic treatment: Incorrect. Viral rhinitis presents with gradual onset and systemic symptoms like low-grade fever; the acute immediate onset after irritant exposure points toward irritative rhinitis.

 

Option D. Bacterial rhinitis; start systemic antibiotics immediately: Incorrect. Bacterial rhinitis usually follows viral rhinitis or presents with more persistent purulent discharge; antibiotics are not first-line in irritative rhinitis unless superinfection occurs.

 

Additional points:

 

  • The severity and duration depend on the extent of epithelial damage and presence of secondary infection.
  • Prevention includes avoiding exposure and protective measures in the workplace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irritative rhinitis presents with acute sneezing and nasal symptoms immediately after exposure to irritant substances, managed primarily by removing the offending agent and supportive care.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 152

choices.text: Primary hereditary atrophic rhinitis with endocrine disturbances
Secondary atrophic rhinitis due to chronic infection and surgical trauma
Allergic rhinitis with hypertrophy of turbinates
Vasomotor rhinitis with recurrent nasal congestion

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of long-standing purulent sinusitis and previous nasal surgery presents with nasal crusting, foul odor, and mucosal atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his atrophic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary atrophic rhinitis due to chronic infection and surgical trauma

 

Secondary atrophic rhinitis occurs due to specific infections such as syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma, or results from long-standing purulent sinusitis, radiotherapy, or excessive surgical removal of turbinates, causing destruction and atrophy of nasal structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary hereditary atrophic rhinitis with endocrine disturbances: Incorrect. Primary atrophic rhinitis is idiopathic and often related to hereditary, endocrine, nutritional, and autoimmune factors, typically starting around puberty.

 

Option C. Allergic rhinitis with hypertrophy of turbinates: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis causes mucosal swelling and hypertrophy but not mucosal atrophy or crusting with foul odor.

 

Option D. Vasomotor rhinitis with recurrent nasal congestion: Incorrect. Vasomotor rhinitis causes nasal congestion and rhinorrhea but does not lead to atrophic changes or foul-smelling crusts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary atrophic rhinitis arises from specific infections, chronic sinusitis, radiotherapy, or excessive turbinate surgery leading to nasal mucosal and structural atrophy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 154

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis causing mucosal swelling on the wider side
Unilateral atrophic rhinitis due to extreme septal deviation causing mucosal atrophy on the wider nasal cavity
Primary atrophic rhinitis affecting both nasal cavities equally
Acute bacterial rhinitis secondary to sinus infection

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with chronic nasal crusting and foul-smelling discharge predominantly from the right nostril. Examination reveals a marked deviation of the nasal septum to the left side. Which of the following best explains the nasal findings on the right side?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unilateral atrophic rhinitis due to extreme septal deviation causing mucosal atrophy on the wider nasal cavity

 

Extreme deviation of the nasal septum results in a wider nasal cavity on the opposite side, which may develop unilateral atrophic rhinitis due to mucosal drying, crusting, and atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis causing mucosal swelling on the wider side: Incorrect. Allergic rhinitis typically causes mucosal swelling and bilateral symptoms rather than crusting and foul smell localized to one side.

 

Option C. Primary atrophic rhinitis affecting both nasal cavities equally: Incorrect. Primary atrophic rhinitis is generally bilateral and idiopathic rather than limited to one nasal cavity.

 

Option D. Acute bacterial rhinitis secondary to sinus infection: Incorrect. Acute bacterial rhinitis presents with mucopurulent discharge and inflammation but does not cause the characteristic crusting and mucosal atrophy seen in atrophic rhinitis.

 

Additional points:

 

  • The wider nasal cavity causes drying and crust formation due to increased airflow and loss of mucosal integrity.
  • Management includes treating the atrophic changes and possibly correcting the septal deviation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extreme nasal septal deviation causes widening of the contralateral nasal cavity, leading to unilateral atrophic rhinitis characterized by mucosal atrophy and crusting.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 155

The disease primarily affects the southern parts of India and mostly females above 50 years of age.
The granulomatous stage is characterized by painful ulcerative nodules and nasal bleeding.
Treatment consists only of surgical correction for nasal deformity without any antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about rhinoscleroma is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting mostly the nasal mucosa and extending to the larynx and bronchi.

 

 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by the Gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). The disease typically starts in the nose and can extend to the nasopharynx, oropharynx, larynx (especially subglottic region), trachea, and bronchi. It affects both sexes and all ages, with a higher incidence in northern India.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. The disease primarily affects the southern parts of India and mostly females above 50 years of age. Incorrect. The disease is endemic in several parts of the world and is seen more often in the northern parts of India than the southern parts. It affects both sexes and any age group, not specifically females above 50.

 

Option C. The granulomatous stage is characterized by painful ulcerative nodules and nasal bleeding: Incorrect. In the granulomatous stage, painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules form in the nasal mucosa with subdermal infiltration causing a “woody” feel to the lower external nose and upper lip. Painful ulcerative nodules and bleeding are not typical features.

 

Option D. Treatment consists only of surgical correction for nasal deformity without any antibiotic therapy: Incorrect. Treatment requires a combination of antibiotics, specifically streptomycin and tetracycline for at least 4–6 weeks, and is repeated if necessary until cultures from biopsy material become negative. Steroids may be added to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is only for airway management and correcting deformity, not the sole treatment.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • The disease progresses through three stages: atrophic (foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting), granulomatous (painless nodules and woody infiltration), and cicatricial (stenosis, nasal deformity, adhesions, and possible subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress).
  • Diagnosis is by biopsy showing plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells (large foam cells with bacilli), and Russell bodies (eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma cells).
  • Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are diagnostic of rhinoscleroma.

 

 

Miculikz cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis affecting nasal and respiratory mucosa, diagnosed by biopsy showing Mikulicz cells, and treated with prolonged streptomycin and tetracycline therapy along with possible surgical intervention.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

choices.text: Foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting resembling atrophic rhinitis
Painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in nasal mucosa with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower external nose and upper lip
Nasal septal perforation with severe nasal bleeding and ulceration
Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress without any nasal deformity

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is characteristic of the granulomatous stage of rhinoscleroma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in nasal mucosa with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower external nose and upper lip

 

The granulomatous stage is marked by the formation of painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in the nasal mucosa. Additionally, subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and upper lip gives a characteristic “woody” feel.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting resembling atrophic rhinitis: Incorrect. This describes the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma, which resembles atrophic rhinitis and is characterized by foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.

 

Option C. Nasal septal perforation with severe nasal bleeding and ulceration: Incorrect. Ulceration and severe nasal bleeding are not typical features of rhinoscleroma; the nodules are usually painless and nonulcerative. Nasal septal perforation is more commonly seen in other diseases like Wegener’s granulomatosis.

 

Option D. Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress without any nasal deformity: Incorrect. Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress is a feature of the cicatricial stage of rhinoscleroma, which also involves adhesions and distortion of nasal and pharyngeal structures. Nasal deformity is usually present by this stage.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, a Gram-negative bacillus, and is endemic in many parts of the world, especially the northern parts of India.
  • The disease affects both sexes and all age groups.
  • It progresses through three stages: atrophic, granulomatous, and cicatricial.
  • Early recognition and treatment can prevent progression to the cicatricial stage and its complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The granulomatous stage of rhinoscleroma is characterized by painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower nose and upper lip.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

choices.text: Initiate streptomycin and tetracycline for at least 4–6 weeks
Start high-dose corticosteroids as monotherapy
Begin anti-tubercular therapy empirically
Perform surgical excision immediately without culture

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from northern India presents with progressive nasal obstruction, crusting, and nasal deformity. Biopsy of the nasal mucosa reveals infiltration of submucosa by plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, and large foamy cells with vacuolated cytoplasm and central nuclei. These cells are found to contain Gram-negative bacilli. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiate streptomycin and tetracycline for at least 4–6 weeks

 

The biopsy findings describe Mikulicz cells, which are large foamy macrophages with vacuolated cytoplasm containing Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Along with Russell bodies (eosinophilic immunoglobulin inclusions in plasma cells), these are pathognomonic for rhinoscleroma. First-line treatment includes streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) for 4–6 weeks, repeated if necessary. Treatment is stopped only after two consecutive cultures from biopsy material are negative.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Start high-dose corticosteroids as monotherapy: Incorrect. Corticosteroids can be used as adjuncts to reduce fibrosis but *are not sufficient alone.

 

Option C. Begin anti-tubercular therapy empirically: Incorrect. There is no role for anti-tubercular therapy in rhinoscleroma, which is caused by a Gram-negative bacillus, not Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Perform surgical excision immediately without culture: Incorrect. Surgery may be needed after medical therapy to relieve airway obstruction or correct deformity, but immediate excision without culture and antibiotics is not appropriate initial management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma is confirmed by biopsy showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies, and is treated with streptomycin and tetracycline for 4–6 weeks, with therapy continued until two negative cultures are obtained.

 

Ref:  P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

choices.text: The early form presents within the first 3 months of life with “snuffles,” purulent nasal discharge, and excoriation of the nasal vestibule and upper lip.
The late form usually appears in infancy and is characterized by mucous patches and generalized lymphadenitis.
Diagnosis is mainly clinical and does not require serological testing or biopsy.
Treatment consists of benzathine penicillin given once, with no need for repeated doses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about congenital syphilis involving the nose is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The early form presents within the first 3 months of life with “snuffles,” purulent nasal discharge, and excoriation of the nasal vestibule and upper lip.

 

Congenital syphilis has two forms affecting the nose: the early form manifests in the first 3 months of life as “snuffles,” with purulent nasal discharge, fissuring, and excoriation of the nasal vestibule and upper lip.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The late form usually appears in infancy and is characterized by mucous patches and generalized lymphadenitis: Incorrect. The late form usually manifests around puberty and resembles tertiary acquired syphilis with gummatous destruction of nasal structures, along with stigmata like corneal opacities, deafness, and Hutchinson’s teeth—not mucous patches or generalized lymphadenitis.

 

 

Option C. Diagnosis is mainly clinical and does not require serological testing or biopsy: Incorrect. Diagnosis is confirmed by serological tests such as VDRL and biopsy with special staining to demonstrate Treponema pallidum. Clinical features alone are insufficient.

 

Option D. Treatment consists of benzathine penicillin given once, with no need for repeated doses: Incorrect. Treatment requires benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units intramuscularly every week for 3 weeks (total dose 7.2 million units), not a single dose. Nasal crusts should be removed by irrigation, and sequestra excised. Cosmetic corrections are done after disease inactivity.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Nasal deformity in late congenital syphilis is similar to tertiary syphilis with destruction by gummas.
  • Early removal of crusts and sequestra helps prevent further damage.
  • Other late congenital signs include corneal opacities, sensorineural deafness, and Hutchinson’s teeth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital syphilis presents early as “snuffles” with purulent nasal discharge and excoriations, while late manifestations mimic tertiary syphilis; diagnosis relies on serology and biopsy, and treatment is benzathine penicillin given weekly for three weeks.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 157

choices.text: Bilateral choanal atresia; provide an oral airway with a modified nipple (McGovern’s technique)
Unilateral choanal atresia; perform immediate CT scan and emergency tracheostomy
Bilateral membranous choanal atresia; wait till 1.5 years for transpalatal surgery
Congenital dacryocystocele; advise massage and monitor for spontaneous resolution

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with respiratory distress and cyclic cyanosis, which improves when crying. Examination reveals mucoid nasal discharge and absence of air bubbles. Attempts to pass a nasal catheter into the pharynx fail. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral choanal atresia; provide an oral airway with a modified nipple (McGovern’s technique)

 

  • Choanal atresia is due to persistence of the bucconasal membrane, and may be bony (90%) or membranous (10%).

 

 

  • It can be unilateral (more common) or bilateral.

 

 

  • Bilateral choanal atresia presents at birth, as neonates are obligate nasal breathers; they develop respiratory distress and cyanosis, especially during feeding.
  • Clinical findings include:
    • Mucoid discharge in the nose
    • Absence of air bubbles
    • Failure to pass nasal catheter into the pharynx
  • McGovern’s technique: Using a nipple with a large hole as an oral airway helps avoid tracheostomy.

 

 

  • Diagnosis can be confirmed by:
    • Methylene blue dye test
    • Flexible nasal endoscopy
    • CT scan (axial view is best)
    • Definitive treatment:
    • Endoscopic transnasal drilling
    • Transpalatal approach usually at 1.5 years (not in the newborn period)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Unilateral choanal atresia; perform immediate CT scan and emergency tracheostomy: Unilateral choanal atresia usually does not cause neonatal distress and is often diagnosed later in life. Emergency tracheostomy is not warranted in this setting.

 

Option C. Bilateral membranous choanal atresia; wait till 1.5 years for transpalatal surgery: Bilateral membranous choanal atresia does need surgery, but emergency airway management is critical immediately. Definitive surgery (transpalatal) is planned later, but cannot be the first step.

 

Option D. Congenital dacryocystocele; advise massage and monitor for spontaneous resolution: Congenital dacryocystocele presents with swelling over the medial canthus, not with respiratory obstruction. It does not cause failure to pass nasal catheters

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral choanal atresia presents with neonatal respiratory distress due to nasal airway obstruction and requires immediate airway support using McGovern’s technique.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 163

choices.text: CSF is secreted by the arachnoid villi and absorbed by the choroid plexus
Total volume of CSF in the body is around 500–600 mL
Normal CSF pressure during lumbar puncture is between 50–150 mm H₂O
Activities such as coughing or lifting weights help seal CSF leaks

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with clear, watery nasal discharge from one side, which increases when bending forward or straining. He has a history of recent head trauma. CSF analysis confirms the presence of beta-2 transferrin. Which of the following statements about cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and its physiology is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal CSF pressure during lumbar puncture is between 50–150 mm H₂O

 

  • CSF rhinorrhoea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose, and it may be clear or blood-tinged, especially in acute head injuries.
  • CSF is produced by the choroid plexus in the lateral, third, and fourth ventricles.
  • Arachnoid villi function as one-way valves: they absorb CSF into the dural venous sinuses, not secrete it.
  • The normal CSF volume is about 90–150 mL, and it's replaced 3–5 times daily at a rate of 20 mL/hour (350–500 mL/day).
  • Normal CSF pressure measured by lumbar puncture ranges from 50–150 mm H₂O.
  • Activities like coughing, sneezing, nose blowing, or straining increase CSF pressure and may worsen a CSF leak; they should be avoided during or after leak repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSF is secreted by the arachnoid villi and absorbed by the choroid plexus: CSF is secreted by the choroid plexus, not the arachnoid villi (which absorb it).

 

 

Option B. Total volume of CSF in the body is around 500–600 mL: Total CSF volume is 90–150 mL, not 500–600 mL (though the latter is the daily production, not volume).

 

Option D. Activities such as coughing or lifting weights help seal CSF leaks: Activities like coughing or lifting weights increase intracranial pressure and may worsen the leak, not help.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF rhinorrhoea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose, and normal CSF pressure ranges from 50–150 mm H₂O.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 163

choices.text: Discharge is salty and slimy
Fluid has <10 mg/dL sugar content
Presence of β₂ transferrin in the discharge
Associated symptoms of sneezing and nasal itching

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with clear, watery nasal discharge from the right nostril, which started after he underwent endoscopic sinus surgery 3 weeks ago. He reports that the fluid increases on bending forward and cannot be sniffed back. Which of the following findings would be most suggestive of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhoea rather than nasal secretions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of β₂ transferrin in the discharge

 

To differentiate CSF rhinorrhoea from nasal secretions, key features include:

 

 

  • The presence of β₂ transferrin in nasal discharge is specific for CSF and is a definitive diagnostic marker.
  • The patient’s history (post-surgical), fluid quality (clear, watery), and positional worsening (bending forward) support CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discharge is salty and slimy: Salty, slimy discharge is more typical of nasal mucus, not CSF.

 

Option B. Fluid has <10 mg/dL sugar content: CSF has >30 mg/dL sugar; <10 mg/dL is suggestive of nasal secretions.

 

Option D. Associated symptoms of sneezing and nasal itching: Sneezing and itching are features of allergic rhinitis, not CSF leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presence of β₂ transferrin in nasal discharge is the most specific test to differentiate CSF rhinorrhoea from normal nasal secretions.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 164

choices.text: Bilateral, multiple polyps with eosinophilic infiltration of the ethmoid
Polyp with an antral stalk, choanal globular part, and flat nasal portion
Arises from the ethmoidal bulla and presents as bilateral nasal masses
Common in elderly with a history of aspirin intolerance and asthma

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and snoring. On examination, a solitary, smooth mass is seen extending from the nasal cavity into the choana. CT scan reveals a lesion arising from the maxillary sinus near the accessory ostium. Which of the following best describes the features of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polyp with an antral stalk, choanal globular part, and flat nasal portion

 

 

The question describes a classic antrochoanal polyp (Killian’s polyp): 

 

  • Origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum, near the accessory ostium
  • Extension:
  1. Antral part – thin stalk
  2. Choanal part – round and globular
  3. Nasal part – flat from side to side
  • Typically:
    • Seen in children and young adults
    • Single and unilateral
    • Associated with nasal allergy and sinus infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral, multiple polyps with eosinophilic infiltration of the ethmoid: Describes bilateral ethmoidal polyps, often eosinophilic and related to allergy/asthma—not antrochoanal.

 

Option C. Arises from the ethmoidal bulla and presents as bilateral nasal masses: Ethmoidal bulla origin = ethmoidal polyps, usually bilateral, not antrochoanal.

 

Option D. Common in elderly with a history of aspirin intolerance and asthma: Aspirin intolerance and asthma are features of Samter’s triad, commonly associated with bilateral ethmoidal polyps, not Killian’s polyp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antrochoanal polyp is a single, unilateral polyp arising from the maxillary sinus near the accessory ostium, with three parts: antral stalk, choanal globular part, and nasal flat part.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
Antrochoanal polyp
Hypertrophied middle turbinate
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with nasal obstruction and a mass seen in the postnasal space on lateral X-ray of the nasopharynx. The lesion appears as a globular soft tissue shadow, with a column of air visible behind it. There is no epistaxis, and the mass is non-tender, does not bleed on probing, and can be moved. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antrochoanal polyp

 

 

This is a classic case of antrochoanal polyp:

 

  • Posterior extension of the polyp into the choana or nasopharynx
  • X-ray lateral view shows globular soft tissue mass in the nasopharynx
  • Column of air behind the mass is a key distinguishing feature from angiofibroma
  • Non-bleeding, soft, mobile on probing
  • Occurs in children or young adults

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:

 

  • Common in adolescent males
  • Presents with profuse recurrent epistaxis
  • Firm, bleeds on probing, no column of air behind it on X-ray

 

 

Option C. Hypertrophied middle turbinate:

 

  • Appears pink, bony hard on probing, not mobile
  • Located anteriorly, not in postnasal space

 

 

concha bullosa

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

 

  • Seen in older adults, associated with neck lymphadenopathy, epistaxis, constitutional symptoms
  • Infiltrative, not mobile or soft

 

Educational Objective:

 

A soft, mobile mass in the postnasal space with a column of air behind it on lateral X-ray is most likely an antrochoanal polyp, not angiofibroma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 175

choices.text: Blow-out fracture of the orbital floor
Tripod fracture of the zygoma
Naso-orbital fracture
Le Fort II fracture

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents after blunt trauma to the left cheek. Examination reveals flattensing of the malar prominence, step deformity at the infraorbital margin, numbness of the cheek, and difficulty opening the mouth. CT imaging shows a fracture involving the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital rim, orbital floor, and anterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tripod fracture of the zygoma

 

 

 

A Tripod fracture (also known as zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture) involves:

 

  • Three key separations of the zygoma:
  1. Zygomaticofrontal suture
  2. Zygomaticotemporal suture
  3. Infraorbital rim and orbital floor (may involve the infraorbital foramen)

 

Fracture also affects the anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, allowing orbital contents to herniate into the sinus.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  1. Flattened malar prominence (due to medial and posterior displacement)
  2. Step deformity at infraorbital margin
  3. Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia (numbness over cheek)
  4. Trismus – due to impingement on the coronoid process
  5. Oblique palpebral fissure – due to lateral palpebral ligament displacement
  6. Diplopia/restricted eye movements – from inferior rectus entrapment
  7. Periorbital emphysema – air escape from maxillary sinus during nose blowing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blow-out fracture of the orbital floor: Blow-out fracture Limited to orbital floor and medial wall, causes diplopia and enophthalmos, but doesn’t involve malar flattening or trismus.

 

Option C. Naso-orbital fracture: Affects medial orbit, nasion, and canthal ligaments, presents with telecanthus, not malar flattening.

 

Option D. Le Fort II fracture: Involves maxilla and nasal bones, not isolated zygoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tripod fracture involves the zygoma at three sites—zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital rim/floor, and zygomaticotemporal suture—causing malar flattening, infraorbital numbness, and trismus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 184–185

choices.text: Le Fort I fracture
Le Fort II fracture
Le Fort III fracture
Zygomatic complex fracture

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a high-velocity road traffic accident. He complains of facial pain and has malocclusion of teeth, elongation of the midface, and CSF rhinorrhoea. On examination, mobility of the entire maxilla is noted. CT scan shows a fracture line extending through the root of the nose, ethmoidal region, superior orbital fissure, and frontozygomatic suture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Le Fort III fracture

 

  • The clinical features described — malocclusion, elongation of midface, mobility of maxilla, and CSF rhinorrhoea — suggest a high-level maxillary fracture.
  • The fracture line in Le Fort III involves root of the nose, ethmofrontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral orbital wall, frontozygomatic and temporozygomatic sutures, and upper pterygoid plates — causing craniofacial dysjunction.

 

  1. Le Fort I , B. Le Fort II , C. Le Fort III

 

  • Cribriform plate injury → CSF rhinorrhoea is a hallmark of Le Fort II and III fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le Fort I fracture: Transverse fracture above the alveolus, no CSF rhinorrhoea, no craniofacial separation.

 

Option B. Le Fort II fracture: Pyramidal fracture with possible CSF leak, but does not involve frontozygomatic sutures or full craniofacial disjunction.

 

Option D. Zygomatic complex fracture: Involves malar prominence, trismus, and infraorbital nerve anesthesia, but not midface mobility or CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Le Fort III fracture is a craniofacial dysjunction involving the ethmofrontal junction and frontozygomatic sutures, commonly associated with midface elongation, maxillary mobility, and CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 184

choices.text: Frontal sinus drains into the superior meatus through the nasofrontal duct
Frontal sinus lies below the supraorbital margin between the two plates of ethmoid bone
Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis
The intersinus septum of frontal sinuses is thick and centrally placed in all individuals

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with recurrent frontal headaches, especially in the mornings, and tenderness above the supraorbital margin. CT scan shows mucosal thickening in the frontal sinus and blockage of the frontal recess. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the anatomy and drainage of the frontal sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis

 

Frontal sinus drains into the superior meatus through the nasofrontal duct: Incorrect. It drains into the anterior part of the middle meatus via the frontal recess. The term “nasofrontal duct” is outdated and incorrect as no true duct exists.

 

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Morning frontal headaches
  • Tenderness above the supraorbital margin
  • CT evidence of frontal sinusitis with frontal recess obstruction

 

The frontal sinus lies above and deep to the supraorbital margin, situated between the inner and outer tables of the frontal bone. Its drainage pathway is through the frontal ostium into the frontal recess, which is anatomically bounded by:

 

  • Middle turbinate (medially)
  • Lamina papyracea (laterally)
  • Agger nasi cells (anteriorly)
  • Bulla ethmoidalis (posteriorly)

 

Obstruction of this narrow and often tortuous drainage pathway by anterior ethmoidal cells can cause frontal sinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal sinus lies below the supraorbital margin between the two plates of ethmoid bone: Incorrect. It lies above and deep to the supraorbital margin, within the frontal bone, not ethmoid bone.

 

Option C. Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis: Correct. This relationship defines the anatomy of the frontal recess, and is crucial in understanding obstruction mechanisms in frontal sinusitis.

 

Option D. The intersinus septum of frontal sinuses is thick and centrally placed in all individuals: Incorrect. The septum is often thin, oblique, or even absent, and the two sinuses are often asymmetrical.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus drains into the middle meatus via the frontal recess, which is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

choices.text: It is thicker and more vascular than nasal mucosa
It is lined by non-ciliated squamous epithelium
Cilia are most concentrated near the sinus ostia to aid mucus drainage
It is discontinuous with the nasal mucosa and ends blindly

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient is diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. Histological examination of the mucosa reveals ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the mucous membrane lining the paranasal sinuses?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cilia are most concentrated near the sinus ostia to aid mucus drainage

 

Cilia density is highest near the ostia, helping propel mucus towards the nasal cavity.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Chronic sinusitis involving the paranasal sinuses
  • Mucosa showing ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells, characteristic of respiratory epithelium
  • The mucous membrane of sinuses is continuous with the nasal mucosa via their ostia, and the ciliary activity is highest near the ostia, facilitating mucus drainage into the nasal cavity

 

This functional arrangement is essential in mucociliary clearance, and impaired ciliary function near the ostia can lead to sinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is thicker and more vascular than nasal mucosa: Incorrect. The mucosa of paranasal sinuses is thinner and less vascular than that of the nasal cavity.

 

Option B. It is lined by non-ciliated squamous epithelium: Incorrect. It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells, not squamous.

 

Option D. It is discontinuous with the nasal mucosa and ends blindly: Incorrect. The sinus mucosa is continuous with nasal mucosa via the ostia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paranasal sinuses are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells, and cilia are most concentrated near the ostia to aid mucus drainage into the nasal cavity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Maxillary sinus mucus can be effectively drained through an inferior meatal antrostomy
Sinus ventilation is similar to the lungs — air enters during inspiration and exits during expiration
Frontal sinus mucus undergoes partial recycling within the sinus before exiting via the natural ostium
Mucociliary clearance from anterior ethmoid sinuses moves towards the sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.text: A 28-year-old man complains of chronic nasal congestion and postnasal drip. Diagnostic nasal endoscopy reveals mucopus in the middle meatus. Which of the following statements about paranasal sinus physiology and drainage is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal sinus mucus undergoes partial recycling within the sinus before exiting via the natural ostium

 

This recirculation occurs just above the ostium and in the frontal recess, making frontal sinus drainage unique.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Postnasal drip and mucus in middle meatus, suggesting involvement of maxillary, frontal, or anterior ethmoid sinuses
  • Understanding mucociliary clearance and ventilation helps identify affected sinuses and choose appropriate surgical approaches

 

Frontal sinus has a unique mucociliary pathway where mucus travels along the interfrontal septum, lateral roof, floor, and exits through the natural ostium. Importantly, some mucus recirculates within the sinus at two points—just above the ostium and within the frontal recess.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maxillary sinus mucus can be effectively drained through an inferior meatal antrostomy: Incorrect. Although inferior meatal antrostomy (as in Caldwell–Luc) may provide ventilation, mucociliary clearance continues to occur via the natural ostium in the middle meatus.

 

Option B. Sinus ventilation is similar to the lungs — air enters during inspiration and exits during expiration: Incorrect. Sinus ventilation is paradoxical: air exits during inspiration due to negative pressure and enters during expiration, the opposite of lungs.

 

Option D. Mucociliary clearance from anterior ethmoid sinuses moves towards the sphenoethmoidal recess: Incorrect. Anterior ethmoid mucus joins that of frontal and maxillary sinuses and passes in front of torus tubarius into the nasopharynx. It is the posterior ethmoids that drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus mucociliary clearance involves partial recycling of mucus within the sinus before draining through the natural ostium.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Sinus mucosa initially produces purulent discharge that later becomes serous
Suppurative sinusitis is usually self-limited and never affects bony structures
Serous exudation is the first step, followed by mucopurulent or purulent transformation
Dental infections usually result in non-suppurative sinusitis due to poor virulence

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with severe unilateral facial pain, purulent nasal discharge, and fever 3 days after upper molar extraction. CT shows opacification and bony wall erosion of the maxillary sinus. Which of the following best describes the likely pathological progression in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serous exudation is the first step, followed by mucopurulent or purulent transformation

 

This is the normal progression of inflammation in acute sinusitis, especially when ostial drainage is impaired.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Acute maxillary sinusitis after tooth extraction, a classic fulminant dental source
  • Clinical and radiologic signs of suppurative sinusitis with destruction of bony walls, indicating advanced infection
  • Pathologically, acute sinusitis begins as serous inflammation, then progresses to mucopurulent and eventually purulent depending on the host immune status, drainage through the ostium, and virulence of organisms.
  • If drainage is blocked, it leads to empyema and potentially erosion of sinus walls
  • Dental infections, in particular, tend to be highly virulent and often rapidly progress to suppuration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sinus mucosa initially produces purulent discharge that later becomes serous: Incorrect. The exudate starts as serous and becomes purulent if infection progresses, not the reverse.

 

Option B. Suppurative sinusitis is usually self-limited and never affects bony structures: Incorrect. Severe suppurative infections can cause empyema and destruction of bony walls, especially when drainage is blocked.

 

Option D. Dental infections usually result in non-suppurative sinusitis due to poor virulence: Incorrect. Dental infections are often fulminant and rapidly result in suppurative sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute sinusitis begins with serous exudation that may become mucopurulent or purulent, especially in fulminant cases like dental infections.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 191

choices.text: Pain aggravated by stooping, chewing, or coughing
Bilateral postauricular lymphadenopathy and otalgia
Nasal discharge seen in the superior meatus
Pain localized exclusively to the frontal region

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with facial pain, fever, and purulent nasal discharge. He recently had a dental extraction of the upper molar. Examination reveals tenderness over the upper jaw and pus in the middle meatus. Which of the following features best supports the diagnosis of acute maxillary sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain aggravated by stooping, chewing, or coughing

 

These actions increase sinus pressure, worsening pain in acute maxillary sinusitis.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Fever, facial pain, and nasal discharge following dental extraction
  • Tenderness over the maxilla, pus in the middle meatus, and pain aggravated by stooping or chewing

 

These are classic signs of acute maxillary sinusitis, the most commonly affected sinus in sinus infections.

 

  • Dental infections, especially of premolars and molars, are common causes due to their proximity to the sinus floor
  • Pain may refer to gums, teeth, or even supraorbital area, leading to misdiagnosis as frontal sinusitis
  • Postural changes and tapping over the cheek (anterior wall) may exacerbate pain

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bilateral postauricular lymphadenopathy and otalgia: Incorrect. These are features suggestive of otitis media or mastoiditis, not maxillary sinusitis.

 

Option C. Nasal discharge seen in the superior meatus: Incorrect. Maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus, not the superior meatus. Discharge here points to posterior ethmoid or sphenoid involvement.

 

Option D. Pain localized exclusively to the frontal region: Incorrect. Frontal pain alone without jaw tenderness is more typical of frontal sinusitis. Maxillary pain can radiate to supraorbital area, but the primary site remains the upper jaw/cheek.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pain aggravated by stooping, chewing, or coughing, with tenderness over the upper jaw, suggests acute maxillary sinusitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 192

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. Imaging reveals a mass in the cerebellopontine angle consistent with an acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma). On microscopic examination, which of the following types of cells are characterized by Verocay bodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antoni A type patterned area in vestibular schwannoma

 

  • Verocay bodies are seen in Antoni A areas of vestibular schwannomas. 
  • Antoni A areas are characterized by compact and cellular regions with elongated spindle cells. 
  • These cells form whorling or palisading nuclei arranged in rows, giving rise to Verocay bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antoni B Type Patterned Area in Vestibular Schwannoma: Antoni B areas are less cellular and have a loose, spongy appearance. They do not exhibit the whorling or palisading characteristic of Verocay bodies.

 

Option C. Both: Verocay bodies are specifically formed in Antoni A regions and are not seen in Antoni B areas.

 

Option D. Antoni C Type Patterned Area in Vestibular Schwannoma: There is no Antoni C type in the classification of vestibular schwannoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) exhibits two histological patterns: Antoni A and Antoni B. 
  • Antoni A areas are cellular and compact, featuring Verocay bodies—an important diagnostic finding. 
  • Antoni B areas, in contrast, are loosely arranged and lack the characteristic structures seen in Antoni A.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents at a specialty clinic with complaints of hearing loss on the left side and occasional facial numbness. His medical history includes episodes of unsteadiness but no severe episodes of spinning or rotational sensation. MRI findings suggest a mass consistent with an acoustic neuroma at the cerebellopontine angle. Which of the following is LEAST likely to be associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute episode of vertigo

 

  • Acoustic neuromas, also known as vestibular schwannomas, are slow-growing tumors that affect the vestibular part of the vestibulocochlear nerve and can impact nearby structures such as the facial nerve and the trigeminal nerve.
  • Due to their slow growth, they typically cause gradual loss of vestibular function, which allows the central nervous system to compensate, hence acute episodes of vertigo (a sudden severe spinning sensation) are less common with acoustic neuromas. Instead, patients may experience mild to moderate unsteadiness over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve may be involved unilateral deafness: This is true as the tumor can compress the facial nerve leading to symptoms such as facial weakness or paralysis alongside unilateral deafness due to vestibulocochlear nerve involvement.

 

Option B. Reduced corneal reflex: The trigeminal nerve (responsible for the corneal reflex) may also be affected by the mass effect of the neuroma, leading to a diminished corneal reflex.

 

Note - Corneal reflex is the first sign of Trigeminal nerve involvement

 

Option C. Cerebellar signs: As the tumor grows, it may impinge on the cerebellum or its connections, causing cerebellar signs such as ataxia and dysmetria.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Acoustic neuromas typically present with progressive unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes facial nerve involvement.
  • They are less likely to cause acute vertigo episodes due to the gradual loss and central compensation of vestibular function.
  • Awareness of these features is crucial for timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Electronystagmography (ENG) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ENG uses corneoretinal potentials recorded via electrodes placed around the eyes

 

  • ENG works by detecting corneoretinal potentials — the eye acts as a dipole with the cornea more positive than the retina. Electrodes placed around the eyes record changes in potential during eye movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ENG is based on detecting auditory evoked potentials from the cochlea: Incorrect. That describes auditory evoked potential tests, not ENG. ENG assesses vestibular function and eye movement, not auditory potentials.

 

Option B. ENG cannot detect nystagmus that is not visible to the naked eye: Incorrect. One of the key advantages of ENG is its ability to detect even subtle nystagmus, including those not visible to the naked eye.

 

Option D. ENG is only useful for recording spontaneous nystagmus and not stimulus-induced types: Incorrect. ENG can record both spontaneous and induced nystagmus, such as caloric, positional, rotational, or optokinetic types, making it a comprehensive vestibular assessment tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electronystagmography records eye movements by detecting corneoretinal potentials using electrodes and can identify both spontaneous and stimulus-induced nystagmus, including those not visible to the naked eye.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 44

choices.text: Acoustic trauma always presents with a temporary threshold shift that later becomes permanent

Exposure to impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the organ of Corti

questions.text: Which of the following statements about acoustic trauma is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exposure to impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the organ of Corti

 

  • Impulse noise (≥140 dB), even for durations as short as 0.2 milliseconds, can rupture Reissner’s membrane, damage hair cells, and cause mixing of perilymph and endolymph, leading to permanent SNHL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acoustic trauma always presents with a temporary threshold shift that later becomes permanent: Incorrect. Acoustic trauma can cause permanent damage even without a preceding temporary threshold shift, especially if the sound is extremely intense and brief, such as in explosions.

 

Option B. Impulse noise from gunfire can reach up to 100 dB SPL, which is usually safe for the cochlea: Incorrect. Noise from gunfire or explosions can reach 140–170 dB SPL, well above the safe limit, and is capable of causing immediate, irreversible damage.

 

Option D. Acoustic trauma primarily affects the middle ear and spares the cochlea: Incorrect. While a blast injury may also damage the tympanic membrane and ossicles, acoustic trauma primarily affects the cochlea, especially the organ of Corti.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic trauma from impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the cochlea, particularly the organ of Corti, leading to permanent sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 34

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SNHL often affects high frequencies and may show poor speech discrimination

 

  • SNHL commonly affects high frequencies first and is associated with difficulty hearing in noisy environments and poor speech discrimination. These are classic hallmarks of cochlear involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SNHL is typically associated with an air-bone gap on audiometry: 
Incorrect. SNHL does not show an air-bone gap on audiometry because both air and bone conduction are reduced equally, unlike in conductive hearing loss where the gap is present.

 

Option B. Speech discrimination scores are usually preserved in SNHL: Incorrect. In SNHL, especially when cochlear or retrocochlear, speech discrimination is often poor, even when hearing thresholds may appear only moderately elevated.

 

Option D. Rinne test is negative in SNHL due to reduced bone conduction: Incorrect. In SNHL, the Rinne test is positive (AC > BC), even though bone conduction is reduced. A negative Rinne is seen in conductive hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensorineural hearing loss often affects high frequencies and is associated with poor speech discrimination and no air-bone gap on audiometry.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 32

questions.text: An ENT Surgeon while doing singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV, has cut its parent nerve accidentally. Which other structure is supposed to lose its sensory supply now, apart from posterior semicircular canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Macule of saccule

 

When considering the surgical procedure of singular neurectomy aimed at treating intractable benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), an unintended cut of its parent nerve would affect the sensory innervation of structures within the inner ear. The singular nerve, primarily responsible for innervating the posterior semicircular canal, originates from the vestibular division of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The question at hand focuses on what other structure would lose its sensory supply if the parent nerve of the singular nerve is accidentally cut.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cristae of superior semicircular canal: The cristae of the superior semicircular canal are innervated by the superior vestibular nerve, a branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve. This structure would not be directly affected by a singular neurectomy.

 

Option B. Cristae of lateral semicircular canal: The cristae of the lateral semicircular canal are also innervated by the superior vestibular nerve. Thus, it would not lose sensory supply due to injury to the nerve associated with the singular nerve.

 

Option C. Macula of saccule: The macula of the saccule is innervated by the inferior vestibular nerve, the same division of the vestibulocochlear nerve as the singular nerve. The saccule is sensitive to vertical acceleration and gravity. If the parent nerve of the singular nerve is cut, it implies that the inferior vestibular nerve is compromised, affecting the macula of the saccule.

 

 

Option D. Macula of utricle: The macula of the utricle is primarily innervated by the superior vestibular nerve. It is responsible for sensing horizontal acceleration. This structure would not be affected by damage to the singular nerve or its parent nerve within the context of the inferior vestibular nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV, accidental cutting of its parent nerve (the inferior vestibular nerve) would lead to a loss of sensory supply to the macula of the saccule, in addition to the posterior semicircular canal. This educational objective underscores the importance of understanding the innervation of the inner ear structures.

Episodes are long lasting (>5 mins)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about BPPV?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Episodes are long lasting (>5 mins)

BPPV is a common cause of recurrent vertigo. Episodes are brief (<1 min and typically 15–20 s) and are always provoked by changes in head position relative to gravity, such as lying down, rising from a supine position, and extending the head to look upward. Rolling over in bed is a common trigger that may help to distinguish BPPV from orthostatic hypotension. The attacks are caused by free-floating otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals) that have been dislodged from the utricular macula and have moved into one of the semicircular canals, usually the posterior canal. With posterior canal BPPV, the nystagmus beats upward and torsionally (the upper poles of the eyes beat toward the affected lower ear).

 

Harrison’s 21st edition page no 160
