questions.text: In BPPV, which of the following canals is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior semicircular canal

 

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) is a condition characterized by episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position. It is caused by dislodged otoliths (calcium carbonate crystals) that move into one of the semicircular canals, disrupting the normal flow of endolymph and leading to inappropriate signaling of head movements.

 

The posterior semicircular canal is the most commonly affected canal in BPPV, accounting for the majority of cases. This is due to its anatomical orientation and the effect of gravity, which makes it more prone to the accumulation of displaced otoliths.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior semicircular canal: This canal is the least commonly affected in BPPV. Also referred to as the superior canal, it accounts for a small percentage of BPPV cases.

 

Option B. Lateral semicircular canal: This canal, also known as the horizontal canal, is the second most commonly affected canal in BPPV. It is less frequently involved than the posterior canal.

 

Option D. Horizontal semicircular canal: This is another name for the lateral semicircular canal, which, as mentioned, is the second most commonly affected in BPPV, but not the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In BPPV, the posterior semicircular canal is most commonly affected due to its anatomical orientation, which makes it more susceptible to the dislodgment and accumulation of otoliths.

choices.text: Cochlear implantation is only indicated for children over the age of 6
Cochlear implantation is not effective in pre-lingual deaf children
Cochlear implantation bypasses damaged hair cells and directly stimulates the cochlear nerve
Cochlear implants are only effective in patients with normal auditory nerve function

questions.text: A 4-year-old child who was born with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss is brought to the clinic by her parents. Despite using hearing aids for the past two years, her speech and language development remain significantly delayed. After a thorough evaluation, the child is deemed a candidate for a cochlear implant. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding cochlear implantation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cochlear implantation bypasses damaged hair cells and directly stimulates the cochlear nerve

 

Cochlear implants work by bypassing damaged or non-functioning hair cells in the cochlea. The external component captures sound, converts it into digital signals, and transmits them to the internal component. The internal component converts these signals into electrical impulses, which stimulate the cochlear nerve directly, allowing for sound perception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear implantation is only indicated for children over the age of 6: This is incorrect. Cochlear implantation is most effective when performed early in pre-lingual deaf children (before the age of 6) to maximize their chances of developing speech and language. The earlier the intervention, the better the outcome for speech and language development in these children.

 

Option B. Cochlear implantation is not effective in pre-lingual deaf children: This statement is incorrect. Cochlear implantation is highly effective in pre-lingual deaf children, particularly when performed before the critical age of 6 years. It allows children with severe to profound hearing loss to perceive sound and develop speech and language skills.

 

Option D. Cochlear implants are only effective in patients with normal auditory nerve function: This is true, but it is not the most relevant point for the scenario. While cochlear implants require a functioning auditory nerve to transmit signals to the brain, this option does not address the mechanism by which cochlear implants bypass damaged hair cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cochlear implants bypass damaged hair cells in the cochlea and directly stimulate the cochlear nerve, allowing individuals with severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss to perceive sound and develop speech, especially when implanted early in pre-lingual deaf children.

choices.text: Nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis typically beats toward the affected side

Vertical downbeat nystagmus suggests a lesion in the craniocervical region such as Arnold–Chiari malformation

questions.text: Which of the following statements about vestibular nystagmus is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertical downbeat nystagmus suggests a lesion in the craniocervical region such as Arnold–Chiari malformation

 

  • Vertical downbeat nystagmus is a hallmark of craniocervical junction disorders, including Arnold–Chiari malformation or degenerative cerebellar disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis typically beats toward the affected side: Incorrect. Purulent labyrinthitis is a paretic lesion, which causes nystagmus to the healthy side, not the affected one. Irritative lesions (e.g., serous labyrinthitis) cause nystagmus toward the lesion.

 

Option B. Nystagmus from central causes is suppressed by optic fixation: 
Incorrect. Peripheral nystagmus can be suppressed by optic fixation, while central nystagmus cannot be suppressed, making this an important diagnostic distinction.

 

Option D. Peripheral vestibular nystagmus is purely torsional and disconjugate: Incorrect. Purely torsional or disconjugate nystagmus (e.g., vertical in one eye and horizontal in another) is typically central in origin, not peripheral. Peripheral nystagmus is usually horizontal-rotatory and conjugate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vertical downbeat nystagmus is characteristic of central vestibular pathology, particularly lesions at the craniocervical junction such as Arnold–Chiari malformation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 41

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a risk factor for hearing loss in children as per the Joint Committee on Infant Hearing (1994) guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Birth weight of more than 3000 g

 

  • Low birth weight (specifically <1500 g) is considered a risk factor. A birth weight >3000 g is not associated with an increased risk and is considered normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniofacial anomalies involving the ear or pinna: Incorrect. This is a recognized risk factor, as structural abnormalities of the external ear often correlate with inner ear or auditory nerve anomalies.

 

Option B. Mechanical ventilation for more than 5 days: Incorrect. Prolonged mechanical ventilation (≥5 days) increases the risk of hearing loss due to associated hypoxia or ototoxic medications, making it a valid risk factor.

 

Option D. Use of aminoglycosides in multiple courses: Incorrect. Aminoglycosides, especially when used in multiple courses or in combination with loop diuretics, are ototoxic and listed as significant risk factors for hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with birth weight <1500 g, craniofacial anomalies, ototoxic drug exposure, or prolonged ventilation are at increased risk of hearing loss and should be screened early.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

questions.text: A case of RTA with multiple temporal bone fractures has presented with facial nerve palsy. On imaging, a portion of the facial canal was found to be oedematous and a bony spicule was found to be impinging on the nerve. A facial nerve decompression was planned. Which of the following surgery needs to be done before going to open the fallopian canal ? (patient had intact lacrimation and stapedial reflex but absent taste sensation)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mastoidectomy

 

In this case of facial nerve palsy due to multiple temporal bone fractures, a mastoidectomy is required before opening the fallopian canal for facial nerve decompression. The mastoidectomy allows the surgeon to access the mastoid part of the facial nerve and prepare the area for decompression.

 

The presence of intact lacrimation and stapedial reflex, but absent taste sensation, indicates that the lesion is in the vertical mastoid segment of the facial nerve. This segment of the nerve lies beyond the geniculate ganglion, where the nerve to the stapedius (which controls the stapedial reflex) and the greater superficial petrosal nerve (responsible for lacrimation) branch off. The cauda tympani, which controls taste, is affected, explaining the loss of taste sensation. The mastoidectomy provides the necessary access to this portion of the facial nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meatoplasty: This is a surgical procedure to widen the external auditory canal, typically used to address stenosis. It is not relevant for accessing the facial nerve.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This procedure involves repairing a perforation in the tympanic membrane (eardrum). It does not provide access to the facial nerve and is not required in this case.

 

Option C. Tympanoplasty: While tympanoplasty involves reconstructing the middle ear to restore hearing, it does not provide access to the mastoid portion of the facial nerve, making it inappropriate for facial nerve decompression in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of facial nerve palsy caused by temporal bone fractures, mastoidectomy is the appropriate surgical procedure to access the facial nerve, especially in the vertical mastoid segment, for decompression.
